description: Possibly a frequentative of skite (“to move lightly and hurriedly; to move suddenly, particularly in an oblique direction”) (Scotland, Northern England). The noun is derived from the verb.

examples: A skitter of activity.A skitter of gooseflesh.

verbs.description: skitter (third-person singular simple present skitters, present participle skittering, simple past and past participle skittered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move hurriedly or as by bouncing or twitching; to scamper, to scurry.
examples: I opened the cabinet and a number of cockroaches went skittering off into the darkness.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make a scratching or scuttling noise while, or as if, skittering.
(transitive) To move or pass (something) over a surface quickly so that it touches only at intervals; to skip, to skite.

description: A frequentative of skite (“to defecate, to shit”) (archaic, vulgar). The noun is derived from the verb.

entries.meaning: (Scotland, Northern England, uncountable) Often skitters: the condition of suffering from diarrhea; thin excrement.

verbs.description: skitter (third-person singular simple present skitters, present participle skittering, simple past and past participle skittered)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Northern England, Scotland) To cause to have diarrhea.
(intransitive, Northern England, Scotland) To suffer from a bout of diarrhea; to produce thin excrement.
